title: Alpinacris crassicauda
text:
Alpinacris crassicauda is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="grasshopper">grasshopper</a> only known from <a href="West%20Coast%20Region">West Coast Region</a> and <a href="Tasman%20Region">Tasman Region</a>, <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. The genus "Alpinacris" is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to the <a href="South%20Island">South Island</a> of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. "A. crassicauda" was described in 1967 by Robert Sidney Bigelow, with a <a href="type%20locality%20%28biology%29">type locality</a> of Lead Hills, Boulder Lake (). A male <a href="holotype">holotype</a> and <a href="paratype">paratype</a> are deposited in the <a href="Canterbury%20Museum%2C%20Christchurch">Canterbury Museum, Christchurch</a>. Like all of New Zealand sub-alpine and alpine grasshoppers "A. crassicauda" has a 2 or 3 years <a href="Biological%20life%20cycle">life cycle</a>. The eggs must ‘overwinter’ before they will hatch. Hoppers are found throughout the year and adult grasshoppers can be found throughout the <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> <a href="summer">summer</a> between December and April. The adult "A. crassicauda" do not overwinter.
Distribution and habitat.
"Alpinacris crassicauda" is only known from <a href="West%20Coast%20Region">West Coast Region</a> and <a href="Tasman%20Region">Tasman Region</a> of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. It can be found as far south as the Right Branch of the Rahu River, Spring Junction () and as far north as the Thousand Acres Plateau, Matiri Range (). "Alpinacris crassicauda" prefer alpine tussock grasslands between , however, can be found as low as on the Thousand Acres Plateau, Matiri Range ().
Species description.
The wings on "A. tumidicauda" are micropterous (small wings) between making this species flightless like most of New Zealand grasshoppers. Male body length ; Female body length .
